page.lettertext:
fol.44r
[Stilo] Ro
m
[To the L.] Treasurer
May it please your good L. sins my last of
e 14
e States
have pressed
Co
r
Stuart
, to specifie w
at
aide
e
K.
doth
requyre, alleadging for themselves,
at they cannot well
determine, w
at
will serve his necessitie, because they
are not well acquainted w
t
e State of
at Contrey, and
sundrie needfull particularities. And heerupon
e
Coronel hath framed his petition, for a 1000 foote and
500 horse, for sixe monethes: whereof I doubt not in
lyke sorte, but he hath notified under hande, to some
principal persons,
at if 3 monethes of it be advaun-
ced it will satisfie
e Kinge. I might be
drawen to conjecture by this forme of proceeding,
at
before it be longe, they will graunt his demaunde,
it seeming a summe of soe small account, as
e K.
hath greater cause to disdaine to crave it, by way
of an Ambassade, then they to refuse to parte with
e money. Nevertheles by
at w
ch
I can gather,
by privat communication w
t
some of
e chiefest, or
can otherwyse learne by secret meanes, w
ch
I doe use
in
at behalf, they are bent at this present to send
him emptie home. Howsoever they shall seale,
this good will come of it in respect of her
Ma
tie
at
considering w
at
caveats I have cast among them,
if they should not thereupon resolve to gratifie
e
K: till they heare how her Hig
es
will brooke of his
motion, it were a great assurance unto her,
at their
interior affections are sownde and sincere. But
otherwise if their haste be soe great to condiscend to
his request,
at they will make no kinde of
request
reckning of her lyking or dislyking, then there might
be just occasion both to speake unto them in other
termes, about
e mater of remboursement, and to
doubt there is some drifte prejudicial to her Ma
tie
,
fol.44v
in this new confirmation of their auncient alliance.
Harangieres
who comaunded in
e Castle of
Huy,
[contrarie]
to all mens expectations of his vertu and valor [hath]
surrendred the place. The Enemie began [his batte-]
rie
e 9 of this moneth, and a breach beyng ma[de the]
next day after, upon offer of composition to [depart with]
bagge and baggage, he presently yelded, w
ch
trou[bles the]
States out of measure, because he bare them in [hand]
in all his l
re
s, and namely by one w
ch
they recea[ved the]
same day, that
e place was given up, that he [would]
holde it for two yeres at
e lest (for he had so l[ong provi-]
sion) though the Enemie should assault him w
th
[fiftie]
thowsand men.
Count Philip
w
t
his forces d[oth rest in]
garrison in
e land of
Luxemborgh
in those three [little]
townes w
ch
were taken by
e
D. of Bouillon
. But [where we]
made account
at they were towardes 3000 whe[n they]
marched from hens, it is reported by one
at i[s newly]
come thens
at they are not now a 1000. [The]
mutined Italians who lie at
Tienen
or Tille[mont in]
Brabant
, have sent their Deputies hither to [treat of]
somwhat w
t
Co. Maurice
, but wherunto it [tendeth I]
can not yet signifie. For they have taken [for a time]
an imprest of
e Enemie, who feedes them stil[l with pro-]
mises, to give them their asking. There [are among]
them notw
t
standing w
ch
say they will come [and serve]
e States, w
ch
in many men opinions were [better lost]
then founde: for
at fewe of those troupes will [doe any good]
service, ether heere or w
t
e Enemie. [Heere is no]
resolution taken for any service to be done [this sommer]
nowe comming: aswell for
e want of those pe[oples]
consent to this contribution w
ch
is not yet past, [as]
because they lacke their forces, w
ch
they sent to
e D. of
Bouillon; and the troupes heere at home are both
fol.45r
fewe and weake in number. So
at all as I thincke
at will
be attempted shall be done in
e
Twent
and
Drent
for
e taking in of
Grolle.
Oldenzeel,
Otmaertsen, and
some other lyke fortes, w
ch
are helde by
e Enemie.
The taking in of Huy was a mater concluded w
th
out
e privitie of
e Provinces, by some fewe among
themselves, and therefore now as I heare, sith
e
event proves no happier,
e common people grudge
at it, and at
e sending of their forces to
e D.
of Bouillon, esteeming it fitter to imploy them at
home, and not to embrace so many actions, in places
so remote, where they have no readie meanes to
seconde their Companies, or to send any rescue.
